article.title: Placing the audience within the story
article.teaser: Combining 360° video with 3D and interactive features will create a whole new viewing experience.

section.sectionBody:
Imagine if we could view video like we view the real world: turn our gaze to a detail and examine it, turn our heads around to see what’s happening on the other side of the room, or open a door to see what’s behind it.
The EU-funded https://www.hyper360.eu/ (Hyper360 project) has delivered a software suite for creating novel video content that would enable us to do just that – and more.
“It offers an end-to-end toolkit for combining 360° and 3D free viewpoint video with interactive items, creating engaging, immersive experiences,” says Angelo Manfredi, Hyper360 project coordinator and project manager at https://www.eng.it/en/ (Engineering), the software company which hosted the project.
The https://www.hyper360.eu/360-tools/ (software tools) developed by the project team cover all steps from creation to viewing: recording, post-production and delivery.

To record 360° video, the solution enables directors to capture sets of large and overlapping images from the scene with multiple types of cameras which are then combined and transformed using https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fisheye_lens (fisheye lens) technology to create a spherical view.
Through the 3D capturing system, they can acquire complete 3D representations of objects or people from all angles. These are then processed by a 3D reconstruction algorithm to embed them into the 360° scenery, where they can be managed and animated to create lifelike avatars.
Interactive elements are added during the post-production phase. “These so-called hotspots can be labels, icons, text or links to other media,” Manfredi explains. Viewers can use a hotspot to carry out different actions, for instance accessing more information about the item, switching to another scene or interacting with an avatar.

Consumers will be able to enjoy this new immersive type of content through computer screens, Smart TVs, mobile phones or VR headsets. The way they interact with the video will be adapted to each type of device – and to each individual viewer: “With permission from the user, Hyper360 can collect user behaviour data and remember viewing choices to build a personalised experience.”
Giving audiences the freedom to select the views they are interested in makes creating a narrative a more complex task. “We need to rethink storytelling,” says Manfredi. “3D ‘mentors’ are one technique directors can use to add guidance for audiences in free viewpoint settings.” These ‘mentors’ are 3D avatars with which the viewer can interact to be guided through the video.
Audiences are increasingly turning to video-on-demand (VOD) services giving them more control over what they watch, with the number of VOD streaming users expected to reach 189.9 million by 2025. Adding elements of gaming to traditional entertainment, Hyper360 is taking user choice one step further by giving them a say in how the narrative unfolds.
While this new type of product is not expected to replace current streaming content, it creates new perspectives for a broad range of audiovisual products. “360° interactive video is for instance a good fit for interactive documentaries, dynamic virtual tours or actionable advertising,” Manfredi adds.
A number of https://www.hyper360.eu/pilots/ (publicly available demos) give a sneak preview of the solution’s possible uses. The full suite has been successfully trialled in two large-scale pilots with major broadcasters RBB in Germany and RTI in Italy.

article.keywords: Hyper360, interactive video, interactive, 360° video, 3D, VOD, video-on-demand, free viewpoint, avatar, fisheye, advertising

article.title: Elderly care with least interference and maximum dignity
article.teaser: For senior care, independent living is infinitely better to hospital or care homes. EU research has developed an open, privacy-savvy ICT infrastructure to help ageing people live with dignity, while maintaining and improving their lifestyle.

section.sectionBody:
Ageing and its associated consequences in terms of frailty, chronic illness and multi-morbidity is challenging health and care systems. Particularly in Europe where the number of older people is expected to rise significantly, health and care models are proving to be inappropriate and unsustainable.
Non-invasive senior healthcare system
The EU-funded http://www.uncap.eu/ (UNCAP) project has developed an interoperable ecosystem targeted to seniors. The key descriptors here that lend themselves to independence and dignity are location, monitoring and assistance.
State-of-the-art physical/cognitive assessment tools are incorporated with technologies to locate objects, devices and users, both in- and outdoors. Monitoring is continuous yet non-invasive, and assists them in case alert conditions are detected. As the project’s coordinating officer, Dr Giuseppe Conti, explains, “This included the development of an interoperable middleware and a software client.”
The middleware enables connection of a variety of different services and applications outside the system such as prescription reminders, healthcare monitoring and fall detection specifically designed for seniors. The software client facilitates their communications with a caregiver via a server.
Pilots at real operational scenarios
Starting in 2016 and extending into 2017, the achievements of the UNCAP system have been assessed by several pilots located in private homes, rehabilitation centres, daily nursing facilities and houses. Throughout various EU countries, involvement of a large number of users and caregivers ensured statistical significance.
Analysis of results of the pilot phase will enable assessment of the impact of UNCAP in terms of return on investment for both public and private care systems, in both financial and societal terms. In social terms, the number of benefits is huge. The reduction of social exclusion and lessening of the burden on health systems and carers, both professionals and family members, must rate as the highest value to the elderly.
Dr Conti points to the testing of the system as extremely key in UNCAP results. “The possibility of testing the overall set of technologies throughout a very large set of pilot sites, with different operators, different care models (formal and informal care), different regulations as well as different cultures has allowed us to identify the most valuable assets for future exploitation of the project results.”
Meeting challenges head-on
The most difficult aspect the team had to face was the administrative and procedural aspects related to ethical approval, which took considerably longer than initially planned. Some of the pilot sites, in fact, required a year to achieve full ethical clearance and this required a complete rescheduling of the pilot activities.
The number of variables in the trial scenarios is so great, that a change in one often necessitated changes in another site. “Dynamic adjustments were essential to ensure statistical and scientific relevance of the results,” Dr Conti points out.
Future steps for successful system launch
The UNCAP project concluded at the end of 2017. The plan is to use a start-up company to bring the results of the project to market. “For this, agreements between the beneficiaries and the company have been established,” states Dr Conti.
The rigorous testing of the technologies developed has been a tremendous opportunity to analyse the real needs of a market with significant potential due to a radical change in demographics, but which is still immature. Data and experiences arising from the pilots have helped identify the priorities and assess services that are most needed for a successful commercial exploitation while maximising the social benefit.

project.teaser: The lack of ICT platforms based on open standards is regarded as one of the most significant market barriers to the creation of new care & assistance paradigms with global interconnection and interworking. UNCAP delivers an interoperable platform based on open industrial...
project.title: Ubiquitous iNteroperable Care for Ageing People

article.title: Step up and follow the exercise routine with a robotic personal trainer
article.teaser: Exercise is good for you at all ages, but older adults are concerned about their safety. EU research has developed a robot ‘friend’ that helps them overcome their reservations.

section.sectionBody:
Despite its recognised benefits, most older adults do not engage in regular physical activity. “To abate some of the most important barriers to this healthy behaviour, the http://www.ict-acanto.eu/(ACANTO) project has developed a friendly robot walker, the FriWalk,” explains Dr Luigi Palopoli, lead project researcher.
Intelligent personal trainer with social awareness
FriWalk can localise itself, sense its surroundings and plan safe routes specifically geared to the user’s requirements. The robot also supports the execution of a training programme, searches for muscular or gait problems, and reports them into the user profile so that doctors and physicians can plan the best physiotherapy.
In order to encourage the elderly to use FriWalk, the second component is a social network that engages them in compelling activities with a social dimension. This social network is based on information that is extracted from physical observation of the user’s behaviour, and it is therefore called the cyberphysical social network (CPSN).
FriWalk in action
“There is a whole bunch of nice outcomes so it’s hard to single out our key results,” Dr Palopoli says. “However, if I had to choose one, developing an integrated robot with a technology readiness level sufficient to test it in a real-life environment, with little technical supervision, is a result beyond my expectations,” he adds enthusiastically. The device has grown from integrated work of different multi-talented partners. A clinical pilot with frail patients in the University Hospital of Getafe, Madrid produced very promising results.
Katerina
Illustrating the ideas and philosophy behind FriWalk is the case of Katerina, a 73-year-old traumatised by a previous fall. Accompanying a cut in exercise level, she has become a little socially withdrawn despite a good level of social awareness.
The tablet suggests a shopping trip, which incorporates running small errands for people, a task that will make Katerina feel useful to other people. The tablet gives her all the help she needs regarding bus to take and the most convenient shops as rated by the CPSN. Due to Katerina’s profile and her doctor’s prescription, FriWalk is confident she could reach her destination, walking 1 km in total, in half an hour. The haptic interface stimulates the correct stepping rhythm while FriWalk adapts the inertia felt by Katerina to her level of tiredness.
To complete Katerina’s social requirements, FriWalk has arranged for her to visit a nice café on the way home where she will meet a potential friend who uses the same device and has a similar profile.
Challenges and team resilience
The loss of one partner along the way (a company that defaulted) had a major impact on work organisation. “The consortium had to brace up and, at the end, produced a wonderful display of resilience,” notes Dr Palopoli.
From a technical point of view, the key problems were related to producing an interface suiting the needs of frail patients. Many iterations were required to make the sensing system operational in any type of environment and to meet the strong safety issues raised by the Spanish Ministry of Health.
Future steps for FriWalk
Following the project end, ACANTO has submitted patent requests and the team is waiting for the results as well as planning a product certification phase. “The most logical business development would be to perform these tasks under the umbrella of a start-up. We are working in this direction,” Dr Palopoli concludes.

article.keywords: ACANTO, FriWalk, social, robot, friend, exercise, cyberphysical social network

project.title: ACANTO: A CyberphysicAl social NeTwOrk using robot friends

result.description: This document will form the basis for collecting, managing and curating the data generated in CONTENT4ALL to be released as open research data in D5.7.
